Quantum mechanics is a beautiful theory. But its mathematical foundations are mysterious. This paper provides a new perspective on the foundations of quantum theory. It shows that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators on the category of sets. This result is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. It is therefore a step toward a more conceptual understanding of quantum theory. It also provides a new foundation for the theory of quantum information.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and compare them to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a minimal structure, and that the genome was reduced to one of the smallest reported in animals. Our findings provide insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease. In this study, we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated transcription factors, which is a key step in the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings provide a potential target for the development of new antiviral drugs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels

Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields. This study quantifies the magnitude of this increase and its consequences for global maize production. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Herbivores are a major determinant of biodiversity in terrestrial ecosystems. However, the extent to which they partition food resources is largely unknown because of a lack of comprehensive species-level diet information. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in body size and digestive physiology. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our findings highlight the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of herbivores in shaping ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We surveyed more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile. Finally, many businesses expect to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a growing problem in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. The origin of silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that the grains have ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga. The grains with ages of <300 Ma condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago. The grains with ages >1 Ga condensed in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium. The grains were not exposed to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The grains were not part of a binary system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950. The expansion has been driven by the motorized fleet, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous, but it contributes only a quarter of the global engine power. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years. The global fleet could double by midcentury, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Reproduction is limited by maternal resources. All forms of provisioning, including domestication, increase maternal energy availability. We show that all forms of provisioning increase reproductive output. The greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alpha-synuclein (α-syn) is a protein implicated in the pathogenesis of multiple system atrophy (MSA), a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. In MSA, α-syn accumulates in oligodendrocytes, leading to their death. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA. VX-765 also reduces the toxicity of α-syn in oligodendrocytes. Finally, VX-765 is able to preserve the number of tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of MSA mice. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising drug to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be achieved by limiting the accumulation of α-syn in oligodendrocytes. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 has been a global pandemic since March 2020. Data on the pandemic are critical for tracking the spread of the disease, understanding its impact, and informing public health policy. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We provide examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to the public health community and beyond.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. An allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter on activation. This structural change is the key event for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. Our findings provide a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. They also provide a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the KcsA mutant channel. Finally, they provide a structural basis for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter in closed-state inactivation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to human health. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products. These natural products could be used as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. This study provides a foundation for future research on the biosynthesis of natural products by anaerobic fungi. This work also highlights the potential of anaerobic fungi as a source of natural products. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Anxiety is a common feature of human populations and is associated with a variety of psychiatric disorders. The underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that anxiety influences social behavior and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the energy metabolism of the nucleus accumbens is critical for social behavior and that this function is impaired in anxiety. Our findings provide a link between anxiety and brain energy metabolism and point to the nucleus accumbens as a potential target for the treatment of anxiety-related social disorders. The design of multifunctional mechanical devices is highly desired for various applications. However, the design space is restricted by the limited knowledge of material properties and the complex and time-consuming process of material synthesis. Here, we propose a digital synthesis approach to design multifunctional structures with desired behaviors. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit irregular material distributions and complex shapes. The physically realized responses are highly complex and unachievable by a single material. The proposed approach can be extended to design multifunctional architectures with highly complex behaviors. The design and manufacturing methods are expected to be widely used in various applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin content of red blood cells is regulated by the expression of the globin genes. The globin genes are expressed in a developmental context-dependent manner. In adults, the fetal hemoglobin is expressed, whereas in fetuses, the adult hemoglobin is expressed. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in erythroid cells and that its expression is developmentally regulated. In adults, IGF2BP1 is expressed, whereas in fetal erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 is downregulated. In adults, IGF2BP1 is expressed at high levels, whereas in fetal erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 is downregulated. In adults, IGF2BP1 expression is associated with a more adult-like hemoglobin profile. In fetuses, IGF2BP1 expression is associated with a more fetal-like hemoglobin profile. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important in the development of hemoglobinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Cancer cells are characterized by uncontrolled proliferation and resistance to apoptosis. In this study, we found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway are resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis. In contrast, cancer cells with loss of function of the phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) are sensitive to ferroptosis. This sensitivity is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis. We also found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic target for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective but have side effects. We show that calcium channel blockers promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of calcium channel blockers in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings may lead to the development of new drugs for treating hypertension. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for forest conservation. It halted clearcutting on federal land and required that old-growth forest be maintained. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area has been stable, but early-seral bird populations have declined. Our findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will be critical to ensure the long-term conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. We used computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome to screen acylide antibiotics. The best candidates were tested in vitro and in vivo. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be used to design new antibiotics for other pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The network architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice. This makes it easier to achieve accurate results in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book before bedtime had reduced melatonin levels and later circadian phase than participants who read a printed book. These results suggest that the use of electronic devices before bedtime may have important implications for sleep, performance, health, and safety. This study also highlights the need for more research on the biological effects of electronic devices on sleep. This is an important step toward understanding the impact of these devices on our health and safety. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1,400-y period of abrupt climate change. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YD cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YD boundary. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the magnetic grains/microspherules is consistent with a terrestrial origin. In contrast, the Os isotopic composition of bulk sediments from the YD site in Belgium is inconsistent with a terrestrial origin. However, the Os concentration in the Belgian samples is low, and the Os isotopic composition of the magnetic grains/microspherules is consistent with a terrestrial origin. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains/microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the YD cooling. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses. However, its specific role in different diseases remains to be determined. Here, we show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This autoimmunity is not fatal, but is accompanied by a shift in the immune response toward a Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance. This may have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals. However, the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles and traced the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. These results have important implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a fundamental principle of the immune system. However, antibodies can mutate and lose their ability to neutralize viruses. This can lead to the development of ineffective antibodies that are unable to neutralize emerging variants. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize antibodies to neutralize emerging variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 variants but not the Delta variant. We show that our algorithm can improve the antibody’s neutralizing activity by ∼10- to 600-fold against SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our approach can potentially be used to engineer antibodies that can neutralize emerging variants. This can help to ensure the effectiveness of antibodies in the fight against COVID-19. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, it is only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and human culture.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apoE allele. APOE is a major component of the classical complement cascade and is highly expressed in astrocytes. Here, we show that APOE is critical for the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in astrocytes, which may accelerate the rate of AD neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate AD neurodegeneration by accelerating the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses. These studies provide a molecular basis for the role of APOE in AD. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the Earth. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. Recent studies have found that the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is a key factor in solving the mystery. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unclear. We have found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core. This study provides a new perspective for understanding the formation of the inner core. It also provides a new direction for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is legal in some states, it remains illegal at the federal level. The legal status of marijuana is a political issue that is often used to justify the need to understand its effects on the human brain. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to the drug is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. Our findings have implications for understanding the brain mechanisms of addiction. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Yet, despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only just beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the most accurate artificial neural networks that predict brain activity during language processing also predict behavior. Our results provide computational evidence that the predictive processing in the brain is fundamental to language comprehension. These findings have implications for theories of language processing and for the development of artificial intelligence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep learning is a powerful machine-learning paradigm that has been successful in many applications. However, it is not clear why it works. In this paper, we show that the success of deep learning is due to the existence of stable neural networks. We prove that stable networks can be computed by fast iterative restarted networks. Moreover, we prove that only a small number of layers are needed for an accurate solution to the inverse problem. These results provide a classification theory for neural networks. They also suggest that deep learning is a universal method for solving inverse problems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community has been working hard to understand the virus and its spread. One of the most influential studies in this field is a classic experiment published 45 years ago. It is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, its design is flawed. This article discusses the flaws and their consequences.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The pathogen has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and the genome of the only cultured strain, M. leprae, is only 17 Mb in size. Here, we report the genome sequence of a second leprosy pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a different clinical condition, diffuse lepromatous leprosy. The two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings suggest that the two leprosy pathogens have been evolving together for millions of years. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related. The entanglement dynamics is usually studied by means of numerical simulations, which are computationally demanding. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood analytically in the space–time scaling limit. We do so by exploiting integrability and the quasiparticle picture of entanglement. Our result is exact and applicable to any integrable model. It opens the way to a systematic study of the interplay between entanglement and thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. It also provides a new perspective on the dynamics of interacting systems.

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering. It is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis and can be spread by multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague is poorly understood. Here, we describe a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague and its control. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is not the only way to measure brain complexity. The number of neurons is the brain’s basic computational unit. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results also suggest that the evolution of brain size is not the only way to measure brain complexity.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be a tumor suppressor. However, the function of TRAP1 in normal cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This may have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin dynamics. It is known to sever actin filaments, but how it does so is not understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to measure the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments and severes them in a mechanical torque-dependent manner. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a general mechanism for understanding ADF’s action in cells. They also provide a platform for developing new tools to study ADF in cells. This article is protected by copyright. Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is widely used in the United States. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food-seeking behavior are not well understood. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Our results have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its comorbidities. Future studies should examine the effects of fructose on food-seeking behavior in the general population. This information could be used to develop strategies to reduce fructose consumption. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar. In addition, we show that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the genomic diversity of other island populations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

People are influenced by the emotions of others. This influence can be transferred from one person to another, even when the two people are not interacting. In this study, we show that this influence can be measured in a large social network. We show that people who see more positive content in their News Feed become more positive, and people who see more negative content in their News Feed become more negative. This work suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with them. This work also suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with them. This work also suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with them.

The ribosome is a complex machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only RNAs that are translated. Messenger RNA modifications can also influence translation. In this work, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in messenger RNA can modestly alter translation. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our findings suggest that messenger RNA modifications can influence translation. This could have important implications for understanding the function of messenger RNAs in cells. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of sociodemographic factors, and they are also robust over time. Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and sentences at the top. However, this description is incomplete. We provide evidence for this hierarchical organization in multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal regions. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to combine words into phrases. This operation is a fundamental component of language processing.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sound sources in their environment. The hearing organs of animals are diverse in morphology and anatomy, but all are part of the body. Here, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to colitis pathogenesis in two ways: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins and by superoxide dismutase (SOD1) and C9orf72 expansion. We report a method to rapidly convert adult human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes. These astrocytes are toxic to motor neurons, suggesting a common mechanism in ALS. We also show that astrocyte-derived toxicity can be overcome by treatment with a small molecule. The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in pathogen colonization. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of gut bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. Birds are a major group of vertebrates, and their evolution is a central topic in evolutionary biology. However, the origin of the avian body plan is still controversial. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, and show that it had a mosaic evolution of flight-related features. This discovery increases the known diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian body plan. The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand it. One way to do this is to understand the role of individual components of the climate system. Here we show that stratospheric water vapor plays an important role in the climate system. We also show that stratospheric water vapor variations are important for the evolution of our climate. This is significant because stratospheric water vapor is not well understood.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal can be used to communicate its identity, warn predators, or blend in with its environment. In some species, the color of the animal is also used to camouflage the animal. In this study, we show that the color of anurans can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein is most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study provides a unique example of the evolution of color and camouflage in vertebrates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors, and is associated with increased proliferation, metastasis, and resistance to therapy. However, the mechanisms that regulate the hypoxic phenotype are not well understood. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is enriched in breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and maintenance. Thus, ALKBH5-mediated regulation of NANOG expression is a potential therapeutic target for breast cancer. This study provides insight into the role of m6A modification in the regulation of breast cancer stem cells. It also provides a rationale for the use of ALKBH5 inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for breast cancer. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Parchment is a material used for making books. It is made from animal skin. The source of parchment has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We analyzed 465 samples, including 72 pocket Bibles. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. However, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. This suggests that ultrafine parchment does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment in the future. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated. The age model reveals that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction. The age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a major barrier against the invasion of pathogens. The intestinal immune system is tightly regulated by the intestinal epithelium to maintain intestinal homeostasis. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) controls the balance of inflammatory responses by dismissing CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Our findings provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. This article is protected by copyright. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human ACE2 receptor. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has resulted in a more open conformation of the receptor-binding domain. This may facilitate virus entry. Our findings provide a basis for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect is not yet clear. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can have a large influence on fire activity and climate. We find that human ignitions can reduce warming by up to 10 y of CO2 emissions. However, the risk of more extreme fires is also high. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand the role of human ignitions in future fire regimes. This is important for understanding the role of fire in climate change and for managing fire in a changing world. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is released by host immune cells just before dusk, when the squid is at its most vulnerable to predation. The glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn use the resulting metabolites to maintain a healthy symbiont population and to acidify the crypts, which enhances the luminescence of the symbionts. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbionts by their hosts. It also suggests that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more common mechanism of host control over their microbial communities than previously thought. Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We first identify a set of vectors that provide a sparse representation of an embedding space. We then infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data.

The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe. However, this interpretation is based on a single reservoir, the rodent population of Europe. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the second plague pandemic. It also has implications for the spread of Y. pestis in the present day. The bacterium is currently spreading in the Middle East and North Africa, and its introduction into Europe in 2013 is a reminder that the disease can reemerge in new regions. Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are also a critical prey species for many marine predators. Mass mortality events of asteroids have been reported in the past, but the cause of the events is still unknown. Here, we report that a densovirus is the likely cause of the mass mortality events. The virus was detected in museum specimens of asteroids, indicating that the virus has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y. The findings have important implications for marine ecosystems. The virus could be used as a biological indicator of ecosystem health. Furthermore, the virus could be used as a biological control agent for asteroid populations. This could be an effective way to reduce the impact of asteroids on marine predators. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge in AML research. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in AML treatment. We demonstrate that antibody-mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. Furthermore, we show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can also inhibit proliferation of primary AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other diseases with a high proportion of stem cells. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar. In addition, we show that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the genomic diversity of other island populations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. Some of these small RNAs encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. The RNA also base pairs with two genes, cadA and galE, and represses their expression. The RNA and protein compete for translation, and the RNA base pairing is required for the repression. This study demonstrates the importance of the translation function of the RNA. This dual-function RNA is not unique to carbon utilization, and may be common in bacteria. This study also demonstrates the importance of the translation function of small RNAs. This is a general principle that should be considered in the study of small RNAs. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a key factor in their success as therapeutics. However, antibodies can lose their activity against emerging variants. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to optimize antibody sequences to improve their activity against variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 variants but not the Delta variant. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that improve the antibody’s activity against the Delta variant. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. This work highlights the power of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to other protein therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be easily adapted to other countries and crops. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the nervous system that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that the firing rates of individual neurons are dependent on experience and that these changes in spiking behavior can support memory. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This study adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is a major evolutionary event in the history of life. It is accompanied by a major change in the molecular evolution of plastid genomes. We present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings have implications for the evolution of plastid genomes in general and for the evolution of the plastid genome in particular in the model parasitic plant, the parasitic plant Plasmodiophora brassicae. The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in 300 years. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This result highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The high-resolution large ensemble used in this study can be used to evaluate the impact of climate change on other extreme weather events. This approach can be extended to other regions and climate extremes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal, with its unique history, provides a unique opportunity to study the conditions under which quasicrystals form. The discovery of this material also demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed under conditions that are not associated with meteorite impacts. This opens up new avenues for the search for new quasicrystal-forming materials. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biosynthesis of chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase” reaction, is the rate-limiting step in the pathway. The cyclase reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one from plants and cyanobacteria, the other from bacteria. Here, we show that the two cyclase enzymes are related, and that they are part of three distinct classes. We discuss the evolution of the cyclase reaction and its role in the evolution of photosynthesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes. We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes reduced neuroinflammation in the later stage of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages played a major role in the generation and maintenance of disease. Astrocytes produced key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed that CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a foundation for developing new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that behavioral flexibility is a converging target of the autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the causal paths that lead to autism. It also provides a model system for studying the molecular mechanisms of autism. This study may also provide a new approach for drug development for autism. This article is protected by copyright. News media are increasingly focused on negative content. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent study of the psychophysiological reactions of 1,000 people to real news video content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive content. They also show that individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is considerable. These results help account for the prevalence of negative news content, but they also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date.

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) channel ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 are critical regulators of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in ORAI1 and STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1. We show that these mutations lead to constitutive Ca2+ channel activity, spontaneous bleeding, and miosis in zebrafish embryos. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated Ca2+ channel signaling, suggest new therapies, and provide a basis for further studies aimed at understanding and treating Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and form insoluble deposits that can spread throughout the brain. Here we show that the spread of polyglutamine-expanded huntingtin (Htt) in Drosophila is non–cell-autonomous, and that Htt aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of Htt aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of Htt aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These findings provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading and the role of endocytosis in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the role of protein aggregates in disease progression. This platform could be extended to other neurodegenerative diseases. (Read more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immunologically privileged. However, the immunosuppressant protein (MTX) identified in this study is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunomodulator that inhibits the antiviral immune response and facilitates viral infection. MTX is also a potent inhibitor of inflammation and is highly stable in the body. These findings provide deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and support the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase. This study also provides a potential target for the development of antiviral drugs. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Cancer cells have a high demand for glycine, a key amino acid. We show that the one-carbon donor of tetrahydrofolate, serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), is a key metabolic target of cancer. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We also show that formate, the one-carbon donor of SHMT, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition. Formate is a critical metabolite in cancer, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We show that formate-dependent glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a metabolic deficiency of cancer. This deficiency can be targeted to block cancer growth. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including superaggregation-prone proteins such as superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), the TDP-43 protein, and the FUS protein. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Instead, we show that the coaggregating proteins have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and suggests a potential therapeutic target. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This article is protected by copyright. The origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood. Some have proposed that the origin of the flowering plants was in a darkened forest habitat, while others have proposed that the origin was in an open aquatic habitat. Here, we present a detailed study of Montsechia, an early flowering plant from the Cretaceous. The morphology and anatomy of Montsechia suggest that Montsechia was an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that Montsechia was sister to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution. This may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that cause a variety of diseases in humans. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from recent years. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising, and it is rising quickly. This is well known, but the rate of sea level rise is not. We report here a 25-y time series of global mean sea level. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating. This acceleration is consistent with climate change. We conclude that climate change is already causing sea level to rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem. In this paper, we show that pain is increasing in the United States, with tomorrow’s elderly reporting less pain than today’s midlife. This is a mystery. We show that the erosion of working-class life is the likely explanation.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state is a key to understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme-substrate complex is also important, as it is the starting point for the reaction. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the enzyme-substrate complex of tryptophan synthase. The structure of the complex reveals the fate of the leaving group in the enzyme-catalyzed reaction. The structure also reveals the isostere of the natural substrate, indole, poised for nucleophilic attack in the enzyme-inhibited state. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of enzyme function. This work also demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into the isostere of the natural substrate. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. Prophylactic treatment with remdesivir prevented disease, and therapeutic treatment reduced virus replication and lung pathology. These results support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial. Remdesivir may also be effective against other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This is an important step forward in the development of antiviral treatments for these important pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn modulates the pH of the crypts where they reside. This pH change, in turn, enhances the luminescence of the symbionts. Our results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients to symbiotic microbes may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. Suspension rates are rising in the United States. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline. This change in mindset was associated with a 50% reduction in suspension rates. The intervention was scalable and cost-effective. These findings have implications for the future of American schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. Here, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a major impact on these emissions. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering outlets is a simple and effective way to reduce the environmental impact of the food system. This study shows that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering outlet increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 61.8% in a large-scale field study. This is equivalent to a 1.5-fold increase in the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. This approach could be applied to other food categories. The results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve a rebound effect, whereby the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased increases at other mealtimes. This study provides a blueprint for replicating and scaling up this approach in other settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is a critical component of the cancer cell. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to reveal how six of the most prominent oncogenes remodel the surfaceome in a cell autologous fashion. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We also show that the surfaceome is a sensitive readout of oncogene activity, and that surface targets can be used to identify potential drug combinations. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a framework for understanding the cell surface proteome in cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings also suggest that vote-by-mail may be a useful tool for election administration in the future.

The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface may be used by SARS-CoV-2 to form unique large-scale assemblies that could have important implications for the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which SARS-CoV-2 causes disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with increased expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated expression of CRFR1 and AQP4 is mediated by CRF acting on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. It also provides a potential target for the development of new therapies for cerebral edema. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is full of associations. We want to know which ones are strong. But we don’t want to be misled by the fact that we have chosen the strongest ones. We need a way to assess the strength of associations that we have found. This paper describes a way to do this.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are essential for blood vessel formation and maintenance. However, the generation of ECs is difficult, and the therapeutic application of ECs is limited. This study provides a new approach for the generation of endothelial cells and their application in the treatment of vascular diseases. In the past few years, two new RTKs have been identified, anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). These two RTKs are oncogenic drivers in human cancer. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, there is no effective treatment. In this study, we found that STING is decreased in islets of diabetic mice and patients with T2D. STING deficiency in β-cells caused impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. STING deficiency in peripheral tissues and β-cells caused insulin resistance and glucose intolerance. STING deficiency in β-cells and peripheral tissues caused a decrease in Pax6 expression. These data suggest that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Thus, STING might be a potential target for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of viral RNA into virions is a fundamental process in all viruses. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We show that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides a molecular understanding of the selective packaging of viral RNA into virions. It also provides a potential target for antiviral drug development.
